info.game_comments:
1997-B Teen Tournament final game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Hogamous higamous, ostrich are polygamous; higamous hogamous, eagles are this

(2, 1).clue: On Oct. 1, 1924, he was born at the Wise Clinic in Plains, Georgia, the first president born in a hospital

(3, 1).clue: You can signify the title of this 1994 Beck hit by making an L with your right finger & thumb

(5, 1).clue: And the Lord said unto him, "Make thee an ark of gopher wood"

(6, 1).clue: It's the honest answer by a Spanish speaker to the question "Hablas espanol?"

(1, 2).clue: The bird's sharp binocular vision gave us this expression for someone with keen sight or alertness

(2, 2).clue: The first presidential airplane, nicknamed The Sacred Cow, was delivered to him in 1944

(3, 2).clue: According to the title of the following, it's what the singer won't tell:

(4, 2).clue: A cover up if we've ever heard one, Tom Sawyer had others do it to his fence

(5, 2).clue: He said, "If I be shaven, then my strength will go from me, and I shall become weak"

(6, 2).clue: "Da" is how to accept an invitation to visit this, the world's largest country

(1, 3).clue: The Latin rapere, "to carry off", gave us this 6-letter term for birds of prey, & for a type of dinosaur

(2, 3).clue: He was the first president to preside over 49 states, as well as 50

(3, 3).clue: This Bob Carlisle ballad about watching his daughter grow was a surprise hit in 1997

(4, 3).clue: Capt. Janeway goes to this when an enemy attack appears imminent

(5, 3).clue: The gospel of Matthew says this governor of Judea "washed his hands" of the guilt for crucifying Jesus

(6, 3).clue: Dutch, Swedish & German "yes men" all use this word

(1, 4).clue: The Bald Eagle is the USA's symbol while this other North American type has been called the king of birds

(2, 4).clue: Graduating from Princeton in 1879, he was the first president to earn a Ph.D.

(3, 4).clue: This group conquered the U.K. & had a big U.S. hit with "Wonderwall"

(4, 4).clue: You look up the value of a used car in it

(5, 4).clue: The Old Testament book about this "virtuous woman" begins, "Now it came to pass in the day when the judges ruled"

(6, 4).clue: This Japanese word for yes sounds like an American way of saying hello

(1, 5).clue: Term for an eagle's nest, often found high in a tall tree

(2, 5).clue: He was the first & only president to administer the oath of office to a successor

(3, 5).clue: On the sound track of "Nothing to Lose", it's when Coolio will "C U"

(4, 5).clue: Reverse the colors on the Swiss flag & you get the symbol of this organization

(5, 5).clue: Once named Saul, he escaped Damascus by being let down a wall in a basket

(6, 5).clue: You'll hear the yes-word "sim" on the streets of Sao Paulo from people speaking this language

(1, 1).clue: In romantic ballets such as "La sylphide", it's traditional for this ballet skirt to be calf-length

(2, 1).clue: Kids roll eggs across the White House lawn on the Monday after this holiday

(3, 1).clue: Some high schools have parties where students trade signatures in these annual publications

(4, 1).clue: They sound short, but these documents Mom writes to present her case go on for pages

(5, 1).clue: The second Monday in October, it's also called Discoverers' Day

(6, 1).clue: A person of no fixed residence who wanders the Earth

(1, 2).clue: A company's leading ballerina is known as this, from the Italian for "first"

(2, 2).clue: This area that existed before the District of Columbia was founded was once known simply as George

(3, 2).clue: This student with the highest academic ranking traditionally speaks at graduation

(4, 2).clue: Rather than criminal, Mom practices this law, & tells me to keep the same type of tongue in my head

(5, 2).clue: In February 1887, Oregon became the first state to declare this September day a legal holiday

(6, 2).clue: Airplanes & stock prices are said to make these sharp drops

(1, 3).clue: It's the weapon featured in "Fall River Legend", Agnes De Mille's ballet about Lizzie Borden

(2, 3).clue: Some 58,000 names are inscribed on this memorial designed by Maya Lin

(3, 3).clue: (Hi, I'm Ben Savage.)  Football games are common at these high school celebrations for returning graduates

(4, 3).clue: Mom's profession is in the name of this document she prepared so our neighbor could act on behalf of his dad

(5, 3).clue: A highlight of Freedom Weekend Aloft in Greenville, S.C. is a race of these craft

(6, 3).clue: A pitcher can walk a batter & still accomplish one of these games

(1, 4).clue: Prince Florimund awakens Princess Aurora with a kiss in Act 3 of this fairy tale ballet

(2, 4).clue: John Wilkes Booth's pistol is on display in this building, where he used it

(3, 4).clue: It's a tradition for girls to ask guys to this dance, which bears a woman's name

(4, 4).clue: Mom bet me that I wouldn't do better on the SAT than she did on this legal licensing test

(5, 4).clue: Tahiti's Heiva Festival centers on this French holiday & is celebrated with canoe races & dance contests

(6, 4).clue: Meaning without a possible positive outcome, it's usually found before "situation"

(1, 5).clue: This Spanish cubist painter designed the scenery & costumes for the 1920 ballet "Pulcinella"

(2, 5).clue: Hsing-Hsing, one of these "giant" Asian animals, is a popular attraction at the National Zoo

(3, 5).clue: From the Latin for "within walls", it's a sports activity played by teams from the same school

(4, 5).clue: Mom shouted, "You go, girl!" in 1993 when this women's rights lawyer was nominated to the Supreme Court

(5, 5).clue: On April 25 this Italian city celebrates the feast day of St. Mark, its patron saint

(6, 5).clue: In naming biological specimens, each species has a binomial one

(0, 0).clue: This co.'s 4-letter name is from Danish meaning "play well"; coincidentally, in Latin it means "I put together"
